fields.Title of Contribution: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) following the ingestion of Dihydroartemisin-piperaquine during a malaria mass drug administration campaign: A case report.
fields.Journal: Malaria Journal or PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases
fields.Description/Abstract:
We describe a case of immune-allergic reaction in a 2-year-old female given a
full course of Dihydroartemisin-piperaquine (Sigma Tau’s Eurartesim) dosed
based on weight at a tablet of 320/40mg per day for 3 days during a
mass treatment campaign in Uganda. In the week following injestion, she
developed a progressive skin rash and blisters which later formed painful raw
areas and was accompanied by a low grade fever. The child was not taking any
prior medications. Blood work was performed (CBC, RFTs/LFTs) and found to be
unremarkable apart from hypo-proteinemia of 4.63(6.6-8.7 g/dl).  Her
constellation of symptoms and presentation were consistent with Toxic Epidermal
Necrolysis (> 30% TBSA), or Steven-Johnson syndrome. Causality was established
as ‘probable’ for Dihydroartemisin-piperaquine using both the Naranjo and the
World Health Organization causality assessment scales. It could not be
established if the causative agent was dihydroartemisinin or piperaquine,
however, the child had previously taken artemether-lumefantrine for malaria
with no reported reactions or repercussions. The child was admitted to the
burns unit and managed with supportive treatment including steroids,
antihistamines, tetracycline ointment for eye care, prophylactic antibiotics,
and meticulous twice daily dressing with neomycin cream. After a good clinical
response, she was discharged after 2 weeks and subsequently monitored for 6
months for the reappearance of lesions. Her recovery was found to be complete
and the child and her caregivers were given a laminated card to be
used at all health facilities, advising against any retreatment with
dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine. The aim of this work is to bring attention of
this case to clinicians and malaria control operations, and to provide and
discuss the details of her successful therapy.
